clinical_study.brief_title: Furosemide Stress Test to Predict Successful Liberation From RRT
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Furosemide Stress Test to Predict Successful Liberation From Renal Replacement Therapy in Critically Ill Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The proposed study will evaluate if a standardised dose of furosemide administered in the 12 hours after RRT liberation can predict successful liberation in critically ill patients. The dose that will be administered is in accordance with the prescribing information.

detailed_description.textblock: Response to furosemide administration is commonly used in clinical practice to assess a patient's potential for RRT liberation. However, this administration is not standardized and practices varies greatly. Rapid recognition of unsuccessful RRT liberation is crucial to avoid further complications such as fluid overload or acid-base and electrolyte disorders. The FST corresponds to the intravenous administration of 1 mg/kg (1.5 mg/kg in previously exposed patients) of furosemide and the assessment of resulting diuresis in the following two hours. FST is able to predict progression from AKI stage I and II to stage III with a high sensitivity (87.1%) and specificity (84.1%), area under the ROC curve 0.87. However, the ability of FST to predict RRT liberation has never been formally assessed.

primary_outcome.measure: Successful liberation of RRT within 72 hours after FST

secondary_outcome.measure: Successful liberation of RRT at ICU discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At time of ICU discharge, assessed up to 90 days post inclusion

secondary_outcome.measure: Successful liberation of RRT at hospital discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At time of hospital discharge, assessed up to 90 days post inclusion

secondary_outcome.measure: Adverse events associated with the intervention

arm_group.description: Patients admitted to participating ICU and receiving renal replacement therapy.

intervention.description: The FST corresponds to the intravenous single-dose administration of 1 mg/kg (1.5 mg/kg in previously exposed patients) of furosemide and the assessment of resulting diuresis in the following two hours. In the 12 hours following the first RRT liberation, a FST will be performed. The test will be considered positive if urinary output is ≥200 mL in the two hours following furosemide administration.

biospec_descr.textblock: Urine sample at D0, D1, D2 and D3 and on RRT restart (if applicable)

study_pop.textblock: ICU patients receiving continuous RRT for AKI

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Receiving continuous RRT for AKI
- Having an indwelling urinary catheter
- Clinical decision by physician in charge to attempt RRT liberation (first attempt)
- lnformed consent signed by the patient himself / legal representative or authorization received from independent physician
Exclusion Criteria:
- Electrolyte disturbances or hemodynamic instability precluding the use of furosemide (sodium > 155 mmol/L and/or potassium < 3.0 mmol/L and/or metabolic alkalosis > 7.50 and/or mean arterial pressure < 60 mmHg)
- Furosemide allergy
- Urine output ≥ 100 mL/h for at least two hours
- Prior FST during the ICU stay
- Known end-stage chronic renal disease at ICU admission
- Withdrawal of life support decision taken before inclusion
- Patient already participating in conflicting research study
